titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.23 Richmond, Va. Tuesday, January 27, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: From Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
From all the information we have from Fredericksburg and its vicinity, we are disposed to believe that there is more importance to be attached to the Northern statements published yesterday with reference to Burnside's movements, then was generally accorded them.
A gentleman who arrived in this city last night, from the army, states that it was generally believed that the enemy were about attempting a crossing some six miles above Falmouth, and that everything betokened preparation for an attack.
It is pretty generally believed that a demonstration will be made during the present week, which will fully develop their movements, and possibly result in another bloody battle.

div3.head: The Confederate Treasury.
div3.p: In the House of Representatives yesterday, a communication was read from the Secretary of the Treasury, in response to a resolution adopted some days since by the House, giving information as to the number of the Treasury notes issued and redeemed, and the amount still outstanding on the 31st of December last. This statement shows the amount issued to October 13th, 1862, to be $291,199,799, amount redeemed, $6,870,120, amount outstanding, $887,329,470. To October 31st, 1862. Inclusive: Issued, $328,015,993; redeemed $11,101,275 outstanding, $3,6,830,715. To November 30, 1862, inclusive: Amount issued, $385,703,900; redeemed, $22,768,675.50; outstanding, $332,915,234.50. To December 31st, 1862, inclusive: Amount issued, $440,678,510; redeemed, $2,013,497.50 outstanding, .

div3.head: The force at Arkansas Post.
div3.p: A Confederate officer from Arkansas Post a few days before its capture states that our force there numbered about 3,500 men. The official Yankee report claims to have captured 4,073.

div3.head: Highly interesting account of the capture of Galveston.
div3.p:
Thinking that you Virginians and our boys of Hood's brigade would like to hear some of the particulars of our New Year's frolic with the Yankees, I send you a short account of it. The expedition was skillfully planned, gallantly executed, and the result was the capture of the city and harbor of Galveston, a large quantity of arms, ammunition stores etc., the Harriet Lane, two large barks ladened with sundry useful things, a schooner and the burning of the Westfield, a fine steamer, carrying eight heavy guns.
Quite a handsome New Year's gift to the Government, wasn't it?
An expedition like the present one had been talked of for a long time, but we had despaired of its ever being executed, until our present gallant leader came among us. His arrival inspired us with fresh hopes, and his skill and energy enabled us to put into action our hitherto fruitless desire to inflick a blow upon our common enemy.
Virginia may well be proud of her many noble sons who are heading our armies, and of none more justly so than of the "dashing Maguler." History will wreathe his brow with unfading laurels.
But to my account.

All the preparations having been completed, the night of the 31st of 1862, found us silently marching along the road from the bridge to Galveston city.
The distance was only five miles, and as the plan was to reach the city about 2 o'clk A. M. we had plenty of time to make the trip leisurely.
Our forces consisted of several regiments of infantry and about 22 pieces of artillery, though the principal attack was to be made by the artillery, as there were only about 310 of the enemy in the city, and they were behind a barricade at the cuter end of the wharf.
The night was a lovely one; the moon looked down upon us, as we stole along, as peacefully as if there was no such thing as war. Perhaps it was in deference to her known prejudices on the subject that Gen Magruder postponed the attack until she had disappeared length the horizon, which occurred about 3 o'clock. Be that as it may, she would have witnessed a very pretty eight if she had deferred setting an hour or two longer.
Well, we reached the suburbs of the city about 3 o'clock. The streets were completely deserted; the few inhabitants who had remained in the city were sleeping soundly, and had we not awaked and warned then of their danger they would have slept on until the cannon's roar had startled them.
Our march through the city was certainly the most quiet procession I ever witnessed.
One might a most have imagined that we were so many ghosts, following the old year to his burial, except that ghosts in the matter of dress have a great partiality for white as a color, and our costume was, as you may suppose, none of the fairest.
But it is not surprising that our usually noisy Texan boys were quiet.

The scene, the dead hour of night, and the fact that this was to be the first battle of many of them, all conspired to make them serious.
Then, too, the great heavy waves came tumbling and roming in from the Gulf, chanting out upon the still night sir, as they dashed along, something that sounded amazingly like a funeral dirge.
But onward we stole, through long, lonely streets now around this corner and now turning that, until at length we reached Strand street, which guns parallel with the water, and is the next one to the wharves.
The moon was now down, and everything was enveloped in darkness; the guns were noiselessly placed in position and loaded the men looking like so many shadows as they took their places in the gloom.
There, within three hundred yards, lay the Harriet Lane, the Owasso, the Clifton, and two other boats, with their broadsides turned towards us, and ready to open upon us the moment we fired.
This we knew, for the Yankees had been ashore the day before and told the people that they knew all about our plans, and were waiting for us. In fact, they were so certain of victory that they allowed us to place our guns in position without firing upon us. All being ready, our gallant General opened the attack by firing the first gun. In a few moments the bright flashes, the booming reports, and whizzing shells told plainer than words that the action had begun in earnest, for the next hour the roar of cannon was incessant.
The clear, been crack of our little lifted guns, the dull sound of our seacoast howitzers, and the mighty thundering bass of the columbiads and 100-pound Parrott guns on the gunboats combined to form a piece of music that might well have been dedicated to the King of Pandemonium.
There was one gun on the Scarlets Lane that really seemed to threw lamp posts; plunging through a large brick house was nothing but fan for those big fellows; in they went at one side and out at the other, leaving a hole through which a horse and cars might pass.--As for bricks, window-blinds places of plank, and such things they flew around in the most reckless manner, evidently viewing with the shells and carrier in making our boys below uncomfortable.

This state of things continued for what seemed to me about one lunar month, though some of my friends and all the other correspondents concur in the opinion that it was only two hours. I suppose the discrepancy occurred from my measuring time by my feelings and they by their watches.
Up to this time, which was just before daylight, nothing had been heard from our boats which were to have made the attack simultaneously with us. The light had raged furiously on both sides, but was fast becoming evident that our land forces alone were no match for the Yankee boats, with their great guns and mortars, which vomited a half pushed of grape and canister at us at a pop. How any of us ceased without receiving one of those nasty pills as a new year a gift, is a mystery to me, for the Janks distributed them in the most miscellaneous and lavish manner.
By the way, talking about gifts let us give the devil his due and admit that in the articles of shell, grape, canister, etc., the Yankees are generous however parsimonious and close they may be in other things.
Won't the army of Virginia and our Texan boys there admit that?
Strange to say, though so much ammunition had been expended, as yet very few casualties had occurred.
To me, being, a novice in such matters, the thing seemed positively inexplicable.
I accounted for it by attributing it to the special Providence which has descreed that balls et omne genus should be blind.
If any other observer on the subject has any other or better explanation to offer we should be glad to bear it. As far as I could learn, Lt Sydney Sherman, son of Gen. Sherman, was the only officer who had as yet been killed.
He fell early in the action, while nobly fighting the gun which he commanded.
The ball which struck him --a Minie — entered his left side and lodged, inflicking a mortal wound.
He was taken to the Convent, which was used as a hospital, where, after lingering a few hours, he calmly breathed his last, another offering on the altar of his country Captain McMahon was shot through the ankle while gallantly commanding his battery.
Several of his men were wounded though I was unable to learn their names.
Might of Capt. Odium's men had also been wounded though none mortally.
I forgot to meet on that early in the engagement a charge was made by 300 of our infantry on three companies of the 42d Massachusetts regiment, stationed behind a barricade at the end of Kuhuts wharf.
The enemy had torn up the planks from the wharf and made a breastwork of them.
Our boys rushed out into the water with their sealing ladders and dashed up them, but the position was too strong and they had to retire, leaving our artillery to shell them out. We lost some ten or fifteen in this charge, and would have lost more, but it was pitchy dark and the Yankees fired very will dy.

Daylight at length arrived and every one was seriously looking for our boats, which ought to have been up two hours before, as was forwards learned, they had come down within light at about 12 o'clock, and, bearing nothing of us, retired fire or six miles, under the impress on that the land attack had been postponed.
There they waited until about 3 o'clock, when the land attack begun.
As soon as Major Smith, who communicated the expedition, saw that the work had begun, he ordered all steam to be put on and started back.
He was then a considerable distance from the city, and was unable to reach it until daylight.
At that time we saw the old Bayon City and Neptune, followed in the distance by the John F Can and Lucy Gwlo, hospital boats, bearing steadily down upon the Harriet Lane, then lying at the end of the wharf, opposite the Cotton Press.
Our affairs just then looked rather gloomy.
Every gun on Strand street had been aliened and withdrawn but two or three light rifled pieces, stationed near Hendley's brick building, which still engaged the Owasco, pouring into her a rapid and well directed fire, which finally compelled her to run up the white flag.
These guns, I learn, were in charge of Lieuts. Johnson, Stringfellow, and Hill, three young officers who came out from Virginia with Gen. Magruder.--They acted gallantly, and rendered invaluable service by engaging the attention of the Owasco while our boats were boarding the Harriet Lane.

But as to our boats.
The Lane had for some time directed her fire at them, but fortunately without effect; but when within about 50 yards the Neptune received several bails, damaging her considerably.
She kept steadily on her way, however, and in a few moments more ran into the Harriet Lane amidship.
Our boys on the Neptune soon cleared the enemy's decks with buck shot from their double-barreled guns, and would have boarded her, but it was discovered that the Neptune was rapidly sinking in consequence of the damages she had received.
She was accordingly run into shoal water, about 50 yards from the Lane, where she sunk immediately, in the meantime the Yankee crew, seeing the predicament of the Neptune, came up on deck again, and were preparing to give her a broadside, when the Bayon City fortunately interfered with their processions by running into the Lane's wheel-hours.
Another volley of buckshot again cleared deck making the Yankee tars dodge into their holes like rats.
Our boys on the Bayon City then boarded her, Major Smith gallantly leading the way, and shooting the Lane's commanding officer (Capt. Walawright) as he leaped upon the deck.
The vessel was immediately surrendered and down came the gridiron and up went our flag.
It was found that the Captain and 1st Lieutenant of the boat were both killed, and about 30 of her crew killed or wounded. --Our loss on the boats was about 16 killed and 30 wounded. Among the killed was Capt. Weir who received his death wound from the bursting of a 21-pounder rifled gun on board the Bayou City.
On board the Neptune, Lieut. Clark is the only officer that I have heard of as killed — the names of the privates who fell I have been unable in the confusion to learn.
Mr. Merryman, of Houston, received a flash wound in the arm, though not very serious.

Too much cannot be said of the gallantry of the men, each and all, who manned our boats; for the enterprise, though eminently successful, was one of the most hazardous and brilliant on record.
Three cheers for our Texan boys who accomplished it. And thus the day was won. The other boats, seeing the box the Lane was in and being still heavily pelled with shells from our guns on shore, shortly afterwards ran up white flags, putting the old gridiron at half-mast.
They then sent in a boat asking a truce for three hours, which we all thought was to end in a surrender of the whole fleet.
The truce was granted.

This occurred at about half-past 7 o'clock.--The three companies of the 424. Massachusetts had also surrendered unconditionally when they saw that the Lane had been taken.
They are a fine looking set of men, handsomely dressed and equipped, and are nearly every one native born Americans.
I was in Virginia about eight months ago and saw quite a lot of Yankee prisoners then, but they were exceedingly low and rough and greatly inferior in appearance to these men. But I must hurry up and finish my account, which I started with the declaration that it would be short.--You must really excuse me for so lengthening it, Mr. Editor, for this is our first exploit on Texas and of any note since the war began, and you ought to permit us to be a little proud of it. You all in Virginia have had so many battles and victories amongst you that you can't appreciate our feelings on the occasion of this our first born.--But my story is nearly told.
The Yankee boats — the Clifton and Owasco.--waited two hours, during which time the latter, I am told, landed a large number of her wounded on the wharf — the result of the skillful handling of our guns on shore.

About half an hour before the flag of truce expired the two last named vessels ignominiously sneaked off with the white flag flying.
They did this because they saw that the Bayou City was entangled in some way with the Harriet Lane's wheel house.
If we could have gotten them loose the whole fleet would have been ours as it was, two escaped, though it is reported that the Owasco sunk after setting out of the harbor.
There is no doubt that she was very seriously injured; for she sat much lower in the water on one side than the other.
The Westfield a fine best, and the flag ship of the fleet, they were compelled to burn, as she was fast aground.
Thus ended the battle of Galveston, fought on the birth-day of 1863.
May every battle that is fought this year end as gloriously for our cause!.
We are indebted to the politeness of Captain Philip Cashmeyer for files of New York and Philadelphia papers of the 23d inst. We make some interesting extracts from them:

div4.head: A Threat by the United States to Expel Napoleon from Mexico.
div4.p: In the Senate of the United States, on the 19th, Mr. McDougal, of California, offered a series of resolutions, as follows:

q.p: Resolved, That the present attempt of the French Government to subjugate the Government of Mexico to her authority by armed force, is a violation of the established rules of international law, and that it is, moreover, a violation of the faith of France, pledged by the treaty made at London 31st of October, 1861, between the allied Governments of Spain, France, and England, and communicated to this Government over the signatures of the Allies, by letter of 30th of November, 1861, and particularly and repeatedly assured to this Government through its Minister resident at the Court of France.

div4.p: Resolved further, That the attempt to subject the Republic of Mexico to French authority is an act not merely unfriendly to this Republic, but to free institutions everywhere; and is regarded by this Republic not only as unfriendly, but as hostile.
Resolved further. That it is the duty of this Republic to require of the Government of France that her armed forces should be withdrawn from the soil of Mexico.

Resolved further, That it is the duty and proper office of this Republic now and at all times to lead such add to the. Republic of Mexico as is or may be required to prevent the forcible interposition of any of the States of Europe in the political affairs of that Republic.

Resolved, further. That the President of the U. States no cause to be communicated to the Government of Mexico the views now expressed by the two Houses of Congress, and that he be furniture requested to cause to be negotiated such treaty or treaties between the two Republics as will tend to make these views more effective.
The resolutions were laid over until Thursday.

div4.head: The guerilla Warfare.
div4.p: A correspondent of the Chicago Times, who accompanied the Federal army on its recent march from Memphis to Holly Springs, Miss., has the following about the guerilla system.

Guerillas swarm everywhere around here, and are remarkably bold.
Our trip out from Memphis was somewhat entertaining in the way of shooting and being shot at. If there were any observing spirits near, whose shadowy forms could fill with impunity among flying buckshot, they had abundant food for ghostly amusement.
Our party was very much like a herd of game running the gauntlets of sportsmen, except that the latter very accommodatingly chose long distances.
Bang, bang — crack, crack — would go the shotguns and cabins from every few miles on the journey, making the route seem like a deer ran, where the hunters, choosing their own convenient stands, opened fusiledee as the game went by. Like phantom horsemen they came and ent, the edge of a dilapidated bat or end of a butternut colored coat tall disappearing among the trees from which the echoing report had just rung out. Occasionally a guerilla horsemen would go correcting down the road, half a mile in advance, sometimes having quite a caviller like appearance, but more often resembling the dashes of Don Quixote as transmitted by wood cuts to posterity — a lean, unshorn, Dillious complexioned rider, clad in thread bare homespun, often patched, and apparently glued to the emaciated animal, which yet went down the road as if the motive power was electricity instead of bone and miracle.
Commence pursuit, and the bushes afforded a ready asylum — Whenever one of our man dropped behind, accidentally or carelessly, even for a moment, some guerillas would generally dash out from the road side and carry him away prisoner to Dixie.
A soldier of Gen. Grant's body guard was thus carried off, although not two hundred yards in our rear, and before these of lit companions who were along could turn to the rescue, sixteen rebels were racing with him in their midst down a lane and into the brush.
Generally the prisoners, after being kept a day or two were paroled; everything of a valuable character, however, being taken from their persons.

div4.head: Lincoln on the financial question.
div4.p: The following message was sent to the Yankee Congress on the 19th:

p.hi: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

bibl.n: message was sent to the Yankee Congress

div4.p: I have signed the resolution to provide for the immediate payment of the army and navy of the United States, passed by the House of Representatives on the 14th and by the Senate on the 18th.
The joint resolution, however, is a simple authority, amounting, however, under existing circumstances to a direction to the Secretary of the Treasury to the payment of the army and navy.

My approval is given in order that every may be afforded for the prompt discharge of all arrests of pay due to our soldiers and our While giving this approval, however, I think it my duty to express my sincere regret that it has been found necessary to authorize so large an additional issue of Treasury notes, when their circulation and that of the suspended banks together have already become so redundant as to increase prices beyond their real value, thereby augmenting the cost of living to the injury of labor, and cost of supplies to the injury of the whole country.

It seems very plain that continued issues of United States notes, without any check of issues to the suspended banks, and without any adequate provision for the raising of money by loans, and for funding the issues, so as to keep them within due limits, must soon produce disastrous consequences; and this matter appears to me to impartial, that I avail myself of this occasion to ask the attention of Congress to it.

That Congress has the power to regulate the currency of the country can hardly admit of a doubt, and that a judicious measure to prevent a deterioration of this currency, by a reasonable taxation of bank circulation, or otherwise, if needed, seems equally clear.
Independently of this general consideration.
It would be unjust to the people at large to exempt banks enjoying the special privileges of circulation from their just proportion of the public burden.

In order to raise money by way of loans most easily and cheaply, it is clearly necessary to give every possible support to the public credit.
To that end, a uniform currency, in which taxes, subscriptions to loans, and all other ordinary public dues may be paid is almost, if not quite indispensable.
Such a currency can be furnished by banking associations authorized under a general act of Congress, as suggested in my message at the beginning of the present on. The security of this circulation by the pledge of United States bonds as herein suggested, would still further facilitate loans by increasing the present and causing a further demand for such banks.
In view of the actual financial embarrassments of the Government, and of the greater embarrassment sure to come if the necessary means of relief be not afforded.

I feel that I should not perform my duty by a simple announcement of my approval of the joint resolution, which proposes relief only by increasing circulation, without expressing my earnest de that measures such as I have just referred to, may receive the early sanction or Congress.
By such measures, in my opinion, all payments will certainly secure, not only to the army and navy but all honest creditors of the Government and satisfactory provision made for future demands on the Treasury.

div4.head: Correspondence about the exchange of officers.
div4.p:
A dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated the 21st says the U. S. agent for the exchange of prisoners, Col. Ludlow, has demanded of Mr. Ould, the Confederate agent, that all the U. S. officers now in the hands of the rebels should be in compliance with the cartel, at once released.
It adds.

Mr. Ould has replied that all the officers now in the hands of the rebels, and captured before the 12th of January--the date of Jeff. Davis's Message-- will not be released on parole, but will be exchanged for those of corresponding rank.

All officers captured after the 12th inst, will be handed over to the Governors of the States in which they are captured, as indicated in Jeff Davis's message. (Colonel Ludlow says all this is in violation of the cartel.) Non commissioned officers and privates will be released on parole as heretofore.
The subject of citizen prisoners is not yet fully settled.
There are now at Richmond 2,000 Union prisoners.
Three transports will leave Fortress Monroe next Friday for City Point to bring them down.
The steamboat New York will leave to-night for Anaspolia with 104 Union prisoners, who arrived here to-day from Richmond.

div4.head: Latest from Mexico.
div4.p:
Advices from the city of Mexico to the 21st of December represent the Mexican people as being thoroughly united in their determination to resist their invaders.
The Mexican Congress had adjourned at the period fixed by the Constitution, and the speeches of the President and Vice President on that occasion show that the honor and patriotism of the people are being fully aroused.--These high dignitaries contended that Mexico is a free and independent nation, and that with her inexperienced soldiers and citizen Generals she will face the renowned armies of France and hand down fresh laurels to history.
The Congress passed an act denouncing all the acts of the authorise appointed by the French, designating them as traitors and usurpers.
So far from their having been any advances of the French on Puebla that stronghold was every day increasing in strength, and now troops were pouring in for its defence--Gen. Ortega, a skillful and indefatigable officer, is in command and the labors of the soldiers on the fortifications were continually increasing.
Hospitals were being established in convenient places, and the ladies were collecting money clothing, &c., for the use of the wounded.
The times "give note of awful preparation."

div4.head: The Maryland Negroes Quietly given up.
div4.p:
Gov. Bradford, of Maryland, having been written to by citizens asking him to protect them by the militia of the State against officers of the Federal Government, who harbor slaves and entice them to run away, responds by saying that ordinarily the militia would be called out, but that he cannot do so now, as the country is in a state of war. Says he believes the Administration is honest and must be supported.
He also inclines to the opinion that when the war is over all loyal suffers will be compensated.
This message gives great delight to the Abolitionists.

div4.head: Peace Prospects.
div4.p:
Col. J. W. Wall, recently elected United States Senator from New Jersey, delivered a speech in Philadelphia on the night of the 19th, in which he recapitulated his miseries at Fort Lafayette, and said: "Fellow citizens: I have received at the hands of the Legislature of New Jersey the high and responsible offices of Senator of the United States.
I go there, my friends, as I understand it, as far as my limited capacities are capable, to advocate peace on the floor of the Senate of the United States."
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M.
Hon. R. M. T. Hunter, of Virginia, in the Chair.
Prayer by Rev. Mr. Peterkin, of the Episcopal Church.
Mr. Yancey, of Alabama, offered the following resolution:

q.p: Resolved. That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into and to report whether an officer of the army of the United States, acting under the authority of that Government, can be made liable and punished as a criminal for the violation of the criminal laws of a State, by a State tribunal, when turned over to State authorities by order of the President.

div4.p:
Mr. Yancey made a speech in support of this resolution, in which he said that he doubted whether when two nations are at war the acts of one could be punished by the State laws of the other.
In conclusion, he said:

q.p:
I am perfectly willing myself to see the policy adopted that every officer of any of the armies of the United States that shall be engaged including service insurrection, and shall against us to murder our families, shall be killed on the field of battle.
That would be justified under the law of nations.
The offence is against the Confederate Government, and it is the duty of the Government alone to take it in hand and resent it by proper retaliatory measures, and not to shift the responsibility on the shoulders of the individual States, by whose municipal laws these offenders, acting under the commend of a foreign Government, may escape punishment.
It is for the purpose of obtaining information on this important question from the Committee on the Judiciary, I introduce this resolution.

div4.p: The resolution was adopted.

Mr. Baker, of Florida, introduced a bill to authorize newspaper to be mailed to soldiers free of postage.
Referred to Committee on Post-Offices.

Mr. Brown introduced a bill for the reorganization of the navy of the Confederate States.
Referred.

Mr. Sparrow, from the Military Committee, reported the bill introduced by Mr. Wigfall to organize engineer troops, with some slight amendments, which were agreed to, and the bill ordered to be printed.

Mr. Clay, of Alabama, presented the credentials of Hon. Allen T. Caperton, of Virginia elected to serve the remainder of the term and occupy the seat of Hon. Wm. Ballard Preston, deceased.
Mr. Caperton came forward and was duty qualified.

Mr. Barnwell, of South Carolina, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill to provide means of paying the salaries voted at the last session for the several officers.
Passed.

The bill for the organization of the Supreme Court of the Confederate States, introduced by Mr. Bill, of Ga., was taken up and considered by sections.
After a long debate on amendments, fixing the number of the judges, on amendment offered by Mr. Hill fixing the number of judges at four, was agreed to.
Pending the further consideration of the bill, the Senate went into secret session.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Peterkin.

The Chair laid before the House a communication from the Secretary of the Treasury, giving information, in response to a resolution of the House with reference to the amount of Treasury notes issued under the several acts, respectively, authorizing the same to the 13th day of October, 1862, to the 31st day of October, 1862, inclusive; to the 30th day of November, 1862, inclusive; and to the 31st of December, 1862, inclusive; also, the amount redeemed and outstanding to the above dates.
The communication was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.

The Chair states that when the House took up the special order on Friday, the business before it was the resolution of the gentleman from Kentucky, (Mr. Crockett) declaring the basic alone upon which peace proportions can be offered or entertained by this government.
Upon this resolution Mr. Crockett proceeded to address the House.
He had offered it through no distrust of the Government, but from information be had received while in his own State last fall he was satisfied that there was a wide-spread feeling in favor of a combination for the formation of a Middle Confederacy to embrace parts of Virginia, the States of Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, and the entire Southern.--He moved the reference of the resolution to the Military Committee.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn., did not rise to appear the resolution, but thought its proper reference was to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
He thought that the resolution was defective in that it falled include Maryland and he was unwilling to give his vote for any resolution that treated that State differently from Kentucky and Missouri although she was not represented upon this floor.
He believed that the great body of the people of that State were as truly loyal to the South as any in the Confederacy.
Mr. Moore, of Ky., obtained the floor, but gave way to a motion to postpone the further consideration of the subject till the morning hour to-morrow.

Mr. Boyce, of S. C., by permission, introduced a resolution that it be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means to inquire and report as to the expediency of raising as large an amount as practicable by excise and stamp duties and assessed and income and capitation taxes.
Agreed to.
Mr. Perkins, of La., offered the following resolutions, which were agreed to:

q.p: Resolved, That the Secretary of War be requested to furnish Congress with copies of the findings of the General Court-martial held at headquarters, Richmond, for the month of January at the cases of prisoners charged with desertion or absent without leave.

div4.p: Resolved further, That he be requested to state under which of the rules and regulations for the government of the army of the Confederate States private L. B. Seymour, company E. 50th North Carolina regiment, was sentenced, for desertion, to receive thirty nine lashes on his bare back every three months for the period of the war, to be branded in the left hand with the letter "D." and to be put to hard labor in Richmond, with ball and chain, for the balance of the war.
Mr. Perkins said he desired to call the attention of the House to this sentence to show that it was against law, or, if in accordance with law, such a law was a disgrace to the Confederacy.

He also presented a bill entitled an act to amend the second section of an act entitled. "An act to provide for the safe custody, printing, publication, and distribution of the laws, and to provide for the appointment of an additional clerk in the Department of Justice, " approved August 5th, 1861. Referred to the Committee on Printing.
He also introduced "A bill to amend the law regarding substitutes" The is as follows:

The Congress of the Confederate States do enact, That in all cases occurring from and after the passage of this act, when, under the provisions of existing law, a substitute shall have been accepted for any person liable to military service, the obligation of the principal himself shall revive upon the desertion of the substitute, duly attested under such regulations as the Secretary of War may prescribe, at any period during the term of service for which such substitute was accepted.
Referred to the Military Committee.

Mr. Villere, of La., by permission of the House, said be desired to notice certain passages in the report of the Secretary of War in relation to the fall of New Orleans, which expressions had been as poisoned shafts to his heart.
The Secretary had spoken of the fall of the city of New Orleans as having taken place "after resistance so feeble as to arouse not less of shame than indignation." He entered his protest against this expression of the Secretary in an official document.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn, thought the Secretary meant to imply that the resistance of New Orleans had been feeble, owing to the gross mismanagement of a former Secretary of War and the present Secretary of the Navy.

The House then took up the special order in Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Curry, of Ala., in the chair,) being the bill, "to declare what persons shall be exempt from enrollment for military service." The pending question was upon the amendment of Mr. Gartrell, of Ga., providing that no person shall be enrolled who has a substitute in the army, furnished in accordance with orders heretofore issued by the Secretary of War.

Upon this amendment the House was addressed by Messrs. Clark, of Ga., and Davis.
At the conclusion of Mr. Davis's remarks the committee rose, and the Chairman stated that no conclusion upon the subject under consideration had been reached.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, of La., the House then went into secret session to receive a report from the Committee of Ways and Means.
--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M by Mr. Brannon, of Lewis.

The Senate were informed that the House had passed a bill for the relief of the Clerk of the Hustings Court of Richmond.
Referred.
A message from the Governor transmitted a report of the Directors of the Penitentiary, accompanied by a recommendation that legislation be had on certain matters therein referred to. Referred.

A second message from his Excellency also transmitted a communication made to him by the Engineers Department of the Confederate States in relation to the exemption of slaves engaged in certain occupations necessary to the preparation of war materials.
Laid on the table.
The Committee for Courts of Justice reported a bill to authorize Town Councils and County Courts to condemn land for hospital purposes.

Mr. Douglas offered a resolution requesting the Governor to inform the Senate whether the companies constituting the State Line have been organized, inspected, and mustered, as prescribed by orders and regulations relating to that service, the present strength and condition of said companies respectively, and the number name, and rank of all officers who have already been commissioned in said Line-or where election entitle them to commissions in the same; also, whether said troops have been paid in whole or in part; by whom and when paid, and whether proper and accurate pay rolls have been made and returned, showing the actual condition of the companies so paid; also, whether any, and if any what, orders have been issued in regard to mustering and inspecting the troops of the State Line, and making returns thereof, the dates of such orders, and the extent to which they have been complied with together with the names and rank of all the officers who have falled to do so.

Resolutions of inquiry into expediency were offered:--By Mr. Frazier, of revealing as much of the act passed December 6, 1861, as to authorize the Governor of the Commonwealth to hire, or cause to be hired, negro convicts to proprietors of iron works, salt works, and to internal improvement companies; by Mr. Garnett, of amending the 11th section of chapter 201 of the Code of Virginia, that County Courts shall be authorized to appoint a less number than twelve men as a special police; by Mr. Ball, inquiring whether the General Assembly possesses the power to re-submit the new Constitution and Schedule to the qualified voters of the Commonwealth, the same having been once voted down by reason of the alarm and excitement existing in the public mind when the vote on the same was taken.
The Senate adopted a resolution fixing a committee quorum at three members when less than nine, and five members in all committees of nine and over.
Mr. Day moved that the Senate, with the concurrence of the House, will adjourn sine did au Saturday, 7th of February resolution rule.
Mr. Gollier presented the petition of citizens of Prince George, asking abrogation of since law as regards them.
The bill relative to impressments of slaves for work on the public defences, was taken up, amended, and recommitted.
The bill authorizing Town Councils and County Courts to condemn lands for hospital purposes was passed; also, bill incorporating the Petersburg Southern Female College.
On motion of Mr. Collie, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p:
--The House met at the usual hour, Mr. McCammant in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows, of the First Baptist Church.

Mr. Anderson, from the Committee on Military Affairs, presented a resolution, which was agreed to, calling upon the Governor to communicate to this House a list of all officers commissioned by him in the State Line, together with the date of their commissions.
He also presented a communication from Gen. J. B. Floyd, which he asked to have printed.
Agreed to.

A message was received from the Governor, declining to communicate to the House, at this time, the correspondence which recently took place between himself and President Lincoln; and also setting forth that Col. Zarvona was commissioned by him on the 1st of July, 1861, and certified to by the State Convention the same day; and that Colonel Z. was at the time of his arrest engaged is valuable services to the interests of the public service, and further, that Capt. Durkee and Lieut. Varner were likewise officers in the State service legally constituted, and were operating in the Southwest at the time they were captured and carried to Wheeling where they were tried for mall robbery, and subsequently transferred to prison in Washington, where they have been since confined.

Another communication was read from the Governor, enclosing the report of the Board of Directors of the Penitentiary; also, another communication from the same source, enclosing a report from the Engineer Corps of the Confederate States, exempting in certain counties slaves from working on fortifications who are engaged in working lead and other mines — all of which were appropriately referred.

div4.head: Resolutions of inquiry
div4.p: --The following resolutions of inquiry were offered; into the expediency of empowering County and Corporation Courts to employ agents and storekeepers to provide citizens with necessary commodities; into the expediency of authorizing the Governor, upon the application of any County Court, to empower them to impress articles for the benefit of the families of soldiers in the public service; into the expediency of incorporating into companies, regiments, and battalions all citizens between the ages of 45 and 9 years, for home defence; into the expediency commanding the New River Navigation act, so also allow the Board of Public Works to impress negroes when necessary.
The bill incorporating the Confederate Express Company was read a third time and passed.
The bill dispensing with the laws in certain localities was called up to Mr. Barbour and amended by adding the the other counties not before enumerated.
Mr. Vadan moved to lay upon the table and upon the vote being taken on it was uncertain whether there was a quorum voting.

A motion was made to adjourn upon which the ayes and noes were demanded.
The motion was disagreed to — ayes 1, noes 70.

The motion to lay upon the table was this withdrawn, and some further amendments with proposed by Mr. Barbour.
After which the bill was engrossed and passed to its third reading.

Mr. Gilmer presented a position from citizens of Pittsylvania county, embodying a series of resolutions adopted by a mass meeting held in said county, relative to extortion, which he moved to refer to the Committee on Courts.
The question was divided — the vote being first taken on its reference and subsequently on the motion to pilut both of which were disagreed to.
The bill to provide for the discharge from active military service such persons as have furnished substitutes, was, on motion of Mr. Treadway, taken up and ordered to its engrossment.

Mr. Staples submitted a resolution, which was adopted, calling upon the Governor to communicate to this House the number of militia called out by his proclamation of the spring of 1862, how long they were in the service, and whether they had received pay for the same, &c.
On motion of Mr. Rowan, the Hours adjourned.

div3.head: Serious accident.
div3.p: --The Jackson (Miss) Appeal, of the 6th instant, has the following account of a serious accident which recently occurred in that vicinity:

q.p:
Yesterday morning the horses and baggage trains of three batteries of artillery--Capt. M. V. D. Corputt's company, from Rome, Georgia; Capt. Anderson's company, from Virginia, and Captain Wydel's company, from Alabama--arrived near this city, and, in crossing the trestle-work at the end of the Pearl river bridge, met with one of those unfortunate accidents against which it seems almost impossible to guard.
The men, horses, and baggage wagons of one company had passed over in safety, but as the second company was approaching the covered bridge the whole trestle structure, several hundred feet in length and about forty feet high, instantly went down, and, of course, precipitated everything on it into the seething flood below.
The utmost confusion prevailed, but steps were taken to render every possible aid. The men who went down were all rescued uninjured except eight.
Of the latter, two suffered severe but not dangerous injuries — the other slight.--About forty horses and mules were known to have been drowned last night.
Many were got out, but some fourteen still remained in the water and on the floating timbers at dark.
Most of the baggage of the men belonging to Captain Anderson's company was in the stream.
One of the officers, who was riding at the head of his company, went down seated upon his horse's back, and, on the timbers reaching the water, neither himself or horse were disturbed in their balance or the latter thrown from his feet.
Rather a long leap on horseback.
The bridge has, we learn, been considered insufficient for a long time, but as it had recently been extensively repaired, no fears were entertained.
Under all the circumstances, when we consider the length and great height of the work, and the flood into which all were precipitated, the escape seems miraculous.

div3.p: Rev. George W. Charlton, member of the Virginia Conference, died in Petersburg on the 25th instant.

div3.head: A chase and capture
div3.p:
--Nicholas Stagar, of Co, C, 1st La Reg't, was arrested by his Captain yesterday, on Main street, above 15th, for desertion.
The officer had the man by the collar of his jacket, and had gone but a few steps towards the prison when the latter slipped himself out of the garment and ran with great speed down the street, turning into 15th street. One of the Detectives of the Provost Marshal being present joined in the chase, and the fugacious soldier retreated into the alley leading to the creek running under Market tridge, between Main and Cary.
Arriving at the stone wall enclosing the creek jumped in, followed by the Detective, both of whom get thoroughly saturated with water and covered with mod. Stegar readed for Cary street, but before getting there retreated into a large culvert leading towards 17th street.--Out of this fleshy hole he was hasten, thoroughly wet and exhausted, and carried to the Military Prison of the Eastern District, where he was lodged for trial.
Three shots were discharged at him by the Detective, but none of them took effect.--He was out and bruised considerably when he jumped into the creek.

div3.head: Set on fire.
div3.p:
--Great alarm was created among the inhabitants of Castle Thunder at 5 o'clock yesterday evening by the cry of dre, which was raised at that hour by the inmates lodged in the second story.
Dense volumes of smoke were found proceeding out of the room occupied by the clerk and sundry other officers.
The door being broken open it was found that the bed and other fixtures in the room were burning furiously, the incredibility material having doubtless been thrown over the grating of the door by some one of the many miscreants confined in the Castle. Ten of the thirty Yankee sailors confined there were converted into bucket men and, under the superintendence of Capt. Alexander, soon succeeded in mastering the flames, the burning remnants of the bed being thrown in the street.
During the progress of this incipient conflagration the women and some of the men evinced the utmost alarm.
Wringing their hands and crying aloud.
Nobody was hurt, and nothing but the furniture in the room was destroyed.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following parties were reported at Castle Thunder on yesterday, viz: Pat Ryan, 4th Virginia Cavalry, absent without leave; Thomas Hunt, alias McDearman, Rodgers's Cavalry, desertion; George T Mathews, Battery No. 4, desertion, sent in by the Provost Marshal of Petersburg; G. M. Thomas, committed as a suspicious character by Gen. Winder; Lewis Wermer, Hawkins's Battery, disobedience of orders; J. B. Myers, supposed deserter from Camp Winder Hospital, and Charles Cloule, Baltimore Light Artillery, desertion.
The following parties were discharged yesterday, viz: Thos Oakley, S. Champion, and Jas Cakley, (delivered to Capt. Ro Caskie, to whose company they belonged;) A Dryefiling and J. F. Roberts, tried by Court Martial for desertion and acquired; Isaac Todd, J. E Gales, and C H. Kent.
delivered to Capt. J. H. Norton, to whose company they belonged.
A number of others were also let out on yesterday.

div3.head: Aiding Condemned men.
div3.p:
--The officers at Castle Thunder succeeded yesterday in detecting a pistol, bottle of brandy, vest of poison, a large knife, razor, and file, that a woman was attempting to convey into the cell occupied by John Mulligan and Dan'l Kennedy, two prisoners now in confinement there under sentence of death by Court-Martial.
Information that these articles would be carried into the cell, if possible, was conveyed to the officers by an outside party, who refused to give his name, but whose information proved correct.
Mulligan was to have been shot yesterday, but execution of sentence was again delayed by the Secretary of War.

div3.head: Appointment of Bank Directors.
div3.p:
--The Governor has appointed and commissioned ne address gentlemen as Directors on the part of the State for the several offices of Discount and Deport, viz: For the mother bank at Richmond, John L. Bacon, David J. Saunders, Garrett F. Watson, and Joseph F. Jones.
For the Branch at Petersburg, Ba Broandnex John B. Wilson, and R A Young.
At Fredericksburg, George H. C. Rowe, Thomas F. Knox, and Wm A Little.--At Lynchburg, George D. Davis, Wm Kent, and Seth Woodruff.
At Danville, Wm H Wooding, Wm Rison, and Wm. P Graves.
At Buchanon, John B Moclick, George S. Penn, and John T. Anderson.

The Governor has also appointed and commissioned the following persons as Directors on the part of the State, for the Farmers' Bank of Virginia and its officers of Discount and Deposit: For the mother Bank at Richmond Richard O. Haskins, S C Robinson, William Rutherford, and Robert A. Mayo.
For the branch at Fredericksburg, J. J. Chew, W. R. Mason, and A K Phillips.
At Farmville, J. B. Hilliard, Wm H. Middleton, and J. L. Walker.
At Danville, John W. Hohand, E.B Estis, and Chas M. Sublett.
At Lynchburg.
H. F. Bocock, Wm. H. Hall, and Wm. A Miller, At Blocksburg, Giles J Thomas, Thomas B Evans, and John Black.
At Winchester, Robt J. Gass, Clerk Cather, and Robt Steele.
At Charlottesville, Wm Dabney, Ro H. Carter, and Samuel G. White, At Lewisburg, John E Bell, John Withrow, and Archilles Rodgers.
At Wytheville, Gordon C. Kent, Ro. Sayers, and David Graham.
At Petersburg, E. C. Hinton, W. L Lancaster, and James M Venable.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire yesterday morning at six o'clock, was caused by the partial burning of the brick carpenter shop owned and occupied by Pearson & Newell, at the corner of 20th and Grace streets. The fire was evidently communicated by an incendiary.
The flames were first observed coming out of the office, fronting on 20th street, where, owing to the want of a draft, the place being closed, most of the destination was confined.
The damage inflicted on the building will amount probably to $250, which was covered by insurance.

div3.head: The Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Early yesterday morning a flag of truce started from Richmond for City Point, conveying nine hundred and ninety-two of the Abolition prisoners captured in the battle of Murfreesborough.
They were all Western men, balling from Onto, Kentucky, Indiana, Missouri, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Illinois.
Another flag of truce will start this morning with 29 more of the same description of captured Lincolnites.

div3.head: Liquor seized
div3.p:
--At a late hour on Monday night Captain James Wright, of the Provost Marshal's detective corps, seized two hundred and fifty gallons of Jamaica rum, alleged to be the property of Leon Drumboiler, a German, and to have been smuggled into the city, contrary to the proclamation of martial-law.
The price article was stored in a Government warehouse until its fate could be adjudicated and determined by the Court Martial.

div3.head: Beating a white Boy.
div3.p:
--Officer Baptist yesterday morning arrested and caged a negro wagon driver named James, employed by the Confederate States on the charge of beating with a whip a small white boy named James Jarvice.
It is said that the fellow inflicted sundry servere bruises on the boy very small boy, by the way.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p: --Security for their good behavior for one year was required of Thomas Lilies, charged with getting drung and disturbing the neighborhood in which he lives; James Brown for fighting in Main street Sunday; James Thay for drunkenness and fighting in the street, and Michael for lying down in the street while drunk.
W James slave of B. Haxall, was ordered to be liked for smoking in the street and waiting with a cane.

Easter, slave of George S. Peton, was committed for trial on the charge of stealing from Julian Israel a pocket book, containing thirty dollars in gold coin, thirty dollars in Confederate States Treasury notes, and several dollars in silver.
Two runaway darkeys were committed to be called for by their owners, and sundry slaves were ordered a whipping for going without passes.

Richard Copeland and Alexander Zollman were arraigned for being proprietors of a fare bank over the saddle shop of D. F. Grooms, north Main st., near 12th, into which the police made a descent on Saturday evening, and captured not only the proprietors, but twenty-odd of their guests, young men from various parts of the Confederacy, and of various degrees of respectability, in point of personal appearance.
The gambling tools, such as two fare tables, box of cards, two dealing boxes, lay out, mahogany one keeper, two sets of ivory chips, and other paraphernalia, were paraded with the captives made on the occasion.
One of the dealing boxes, with the "ace on top," was displayed by the side of His Honor, together with the layout, (or betting cloth,) so that the officers could be enabled to explain the progress of the game at the time of their entrance into the room where the tiger was being exhibited.

Messrs. Davis and Crone, policemen, certified as to the manner in which Copeland was pulling the cards out of the box when they entered.
Not suspecting their proximity, he continued his work until about one third of the cards had been pulled out. While this was being done, "a fair haired gentleman," whose name they didn't know, went his 'pile' on the tray, while two others put some ivory (the technical name of which the officers did not know) on the ten spot and queen.
Before a turn could be made for the money, the officers closed the deal by seizing Copeland and his tools.
Consternation among the whole party ensued.
Davis, one of the officers, got hold of a cue box, and found in it a large pile of money, which Copeland expressed great anxiety to get, but he would not let him.

The parties found in the room other than the dealers, were required yesterday to answer to the charge of being found at the "bank" and for being persons without visible means of support.
Some few showed that they were soldiers, with doubtful claims to be considered rightfully away from their regiments, but the great majority confessed themselves gentlemen of elegant leisure.
All of the spectators in the room were required to give security for their good behavior, which they did, save E. M. Ezckiel, who proved be had gone there to collect a bill, and was discharged.
Richard Copeland gave $6,000 bail to answer before the Grand Jury on the second Monday in February.
The case of Zollman, one of the reputed proprietors, was continued till Wednesday, the proof in his case not being very clear.

div3.head: Important from North Carolina.
div3.p: --A respectable refugee, just arrived from Beaufort, reports the Abolition fleet ninety-two sail, including two Monitors and six other iron-clads, in Beaufort harbor; also, that 52,000 Abolitionists are encamped at Morehead City and Carolina City.

Gen. Robertson has just returned to Kinston from a reconnoitering expedition through Jones and Onslow counties.
He reports that a company of cavalry (Capt. Perkins) surprised a party of Abolitionists last Friday at Big Northeast Bridge, near Jacksonville, (Onslow Court House.) Killing a Captain and five privates and routing the balance.
Notice on outside.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p: --The State Journal's Kinston correspondent says it is reported that the enemy is advancing from Newborn in two columns, one towards Kinston, the other towards Wilmington.

Nothing important in the Legislature.
The Military bill was postponed until Wednesday.

div3.head: Attack on Gen. Morgan.
div3.p: --The Advertiser and Register has received a dispatch, dated McMinnville, Jan. 24th, which says:

q.p:
"The enemy, 5,000 strong, attacked one of Morgan's regiments, under command of Colonel Hutchinson, st Woodburg this morning.
Our man, after two hours fighting with a superior force, fell back two miles, with the loss of three men killed, including Col Hutchinson, and nine wounded. The enemy loss in unknown.

div3.p:
Commissioner's Sale of two Tenements, on 18th and Venable streets, and valuable Lot on Broad between 21st and 23d sts. The undersigned, Commissioners, appointed by the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond in the styled "Ryan &sts.
vs. McCarthy & als," will, on Monday, 2d February, 1863, beginning at r o'clk. P. M., proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, the following property, to wit:
A lot of Land fronting on 18th street, near its intersection with Venable street, 47 feet 3 inches , on which stands a good framed tenement.
A Lot of Land on the South side of Broad street, between 21st and 22d sts, fronting 25 feet and running back 100 feet.

TermsOne-third each; the balance on a credit of 5 and 12 months, interest money is paid and a conveyance directed by the Court.
If the purchasers desire it the whole purchase money may be paid in cash.

The title is believed to be good, the Commissioners will convey, however, with special warranty.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchasers.
div3.closer:
Wm. F. Watson, Comm'rs.
Alex K. Sands, Comm'rs.
Sale conducted by Goddin & Apperson, Auctioners. ja 21--tds

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 23, page 2.

div3.head: Lord Russell and the Cotton Famine.
div3.p:
"Whatsoever folly Kings commit, their subjects are punished for it," says Horace, drawing this maxim from the pages of Homer, which he tells us he had just been reading with particular attention.
The people of England have a better right to know the truth of this maxim than any other people of modern days.
To the stupid policy of Lord John Russell they owe the greatest calamity that has ever befallen them since the Conquest — a calamity which that so called stateman had it in his power not only to have averted, but to have rendered impossible in all future time.
A stupid adherence to old maxims of Government, not at all applicable to the present state of the world, was the cause of his inflicting this great misfortune upon his country.

Eighty years ago, when Commissioners from England and America were settling the treaty of peace, the American Commissioners, instigated by Dr. Franklin, who was one of them, proposed to abolish the right of capture at sea, in time of war, all private property by all vessels of the belligerents, either public or private.
To this the British Commissioner, David Hartley, would by no means consent.
He was a thick-skulled formalist, like Lord John Russell, and know nothing of trade and its requirements more than he was able to gather from the pages of Grotfus and Puffertdorff.
In his autobiographical memoirs.
Mr. Jefferson expresses his surprise at this singular refusal, the English having at the time the largest commerce in the world, and we comparatively none. "As hawks abound where there is most game," argued this acute statesman, "so will our privateers swarm over the ocean, in the event of a war." --In this Convention of Paris, in 1856, an effort was made to correct this mistake, in part.
The several nations formally agreed to abolish privateering, but, with a stupidity peculiar to Lord Russell, they still retained the legality of capture by regularly commissioned ships.
The United States offered to become a party on condition that the rule were made absolute, and that all capture of private property at sea should be prohibited.
Still the English Government clung to the antiquated folly, grown venerable no doubt from its age. At last, in 1859, only three years and a half ago, the Government of Mr. Buchanan proposed to abolish the blockade of all commercial ports.
The following is an extract from the letter of General Cass, written while the Italian war was still raging, and the Government was under apprehensions that it might spread so as to involve all Europe.
It is dated 27th June, 1859:

q.p:
"The blockade of an enemy's coast, in order to prevent all intercourse with neutrals, even for the most peaceful purposes, is a claim that gains no additional strength by an investigation into the foundation on which it rests and the evils which have accompanied its exercise call for an efficient remedy.
The investment of a place by sea and land, preventing it from receiving supplies of men and material necessary for its defence, is a legitimate mode of prosecuting hostilities which cannot be objected to; so long as war is recognized as an arbiter of national disputes.
But the blockade of a coast, or of commercial positions along it, without any regard to ulterior military operations, and with the real design of carrying on a war against trade, and, from its very nature, against the trade of peaceful and friendly Powers, instead of a war against armed men, is a proceeding which it is difficult to reconcile with reason or the opinions of modern times.
To watch every creek, and river, and harbor, upon an ocean frontier in order to seize and confiscate every vessel with its cargo attempting to enter or go out, without any direct effect upon the true objects of war, is a mode of conducting hostilities which would find few advocates if now first presented for consideration"

div3.p:
This note concluded with a direct proposition to abolish all blockades of peaceful posts, and to confine all future blockades to arsenals.
This proposal Lord Russell would not listen to, and when questioned on the subject in the House of Commons, even so late as February, 1861, said, "It is for our (English) interests that commercial blockades should be maintained;" adding that "he would not listen to a proposal for putting amend to them and that it was necessary for England, as a great Maritime Power, to possess the right of blockade." In two months from that time England's supply of cotton was entirely out off by the Yankee blockade, and England is now in the very midst of the greatest calamity she ever suffered.

div3.head: The Yankee character Illustrated.
div3.p: --The following is an extract from a private letter of an officer in our army at Fredericksburg:

q.p:
"Four or five Yankees brought a sick negro to the banks of the river t'other day and forced him into the water, telling him to swim or die; the negro begged hard, but the Yankees were inexorable.
One of them gave him a plank, however, and the poor wretch after pulling off his his clothes, was forced into the river.
Our pickets threw him a but as he was staggering but of the water they discovered that he was frightfully covered with small pox. In their momentary horror at this they let the tope drop and the poor wretch back and was drowned.
While struggling in the water the Yankees cried out, "Take your a — d riggers, he is worth $2,000 to you, and nothing to us. This incident I know to be true.
The General regretted very much afterwards that our pickets and not fired upon the murderers"

div4.p: On the 8th instant, by Rev. James R. Gates, Mr. Wm. E. Baston to Miss. Mary Carrona, all of Henrico.
On the evening of the 14th instant, by Rev. James E. Gates, Mr. James Reith, of South Carolina to Miss Mariah C Blaylock, of Richmond. *
On Sunday afternoon, the 25th inst., Frederick Peyton Smith, youngest son of Mary L and the late Frederick P. Smith, in the 19th year of his age.

lg.l: A light is from our household gone,
A voice we loved is slided,
A place is vacant at our hearth
Which never can be filled,
A gentle heart, that throbbed but now
With underness and love,
Has hushed its weary throbbings here
To throb in bites above,
Yes, to the home where ange's are
His trusting soul has fled,
And yet we bend above the tomb
With tears and call him dead,

We call him dead; but, ah!
we know
He dwells where living waters flow.

div4.p: His funeral will take place from Clay Street Church, this (Tuesday) morning, at 10 o'clock. --The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
On the 20th inst, of congestive chills, James William Martin, in the 21st year of his age, only son of Della and Andrew Martin, of Carolina county, Va.

lg.l: Lay him gently in the coffin,
Wrap the cold, white shround around him,
Fold his arms across his breast,
Our darling Jimmy has gone to rest.
Oh ! my heart is sad and lonely,
As I weep above thy bed,
And my home is lone and dreary,
For my darling Jimmy's dead.
Why do we mourn departing
Friends, or shake at Death's alarm;
Tis but the void that Jesus sends
To call them to his arms.

div4.p: On Tuesday, Jan'y 21st, John Lane, youngest son of William and Sarah F. Mingle, aged 21 months. *

In Manchester, Chesterfield county, Va., on the 24th instant, at half-past 9 o'clock P. M., after a short-illness of small-pox, Henrietta Jafe, second daughter of Wm.
H and Mary Ann Wymack, aged 3 years and 4 months. *

div3.p:
Fifty Dollars reward will be paid for the delivery to Messrs. Richardson & Co., 95 Main street, Richmond, of a Coit's new patent fluted cylinder Six Shootee, No. 462.
which, with a fine ivory handled Wosternholm's Knife, mounted on a superior sword belt, were left in the cars that arrived at this place from Danville, on the morning of the 23d of January.

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Estrayed from my house, on the 19th instant, a red Sow, with black spots on her body, I will give the above reward to any person that will deliver her to me or give me some information about her so I can get her stony residence, on the plankroad, opposite Camp Winder.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--For the 15th Regiment Va Cavalry, for which a good horse, saddle, and all necessary equipments will be furnished and a liberal price paid.
Apply at once at Ward A. General Hospital No. 12, corner of 19th and Franklin streets, between the hours of 9 and 3, till 31st January.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--For the war. This Substitute may have the privilege of joining any branch of the service he may wash.
He must be over forty-five years old. A good price will be paid.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--We wish to employ a Substitute.
He can have the privilege or going into any kind of service or company.
To one well recommended a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at once to

Pollard & Walker,
Cary street, ja 27--1t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Substitute, to call at the Columbian Hotel, No. 13, from 8 to 10 o' clock A. M., or from 1 to 4 P. M., to-day, to whom a liberal price will be paid.
None need apply under forty- five.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. Must be a citizen of the Confederate States and over 45.
Apply at No. 43, American Hotel, between the hours of 10 and 12 A. M.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--One over 45 years of age and who can come well recommended.
Apply to day, at 31 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Substitute
div3.p:
--A native of this State will go as a Substitute for $2,500. He is 47 years of age and strong and healthy.
Address "A P H," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the army near Fredericksburg.
None need apply who are under 45 years old. Apply at Room No. 25 Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A good reliable man, over 45 years of age, will receive a liberal place for his services.
Apply at Hill's Ambrotype Gallery, 188 Broad st.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, an able bodied man over 45 years, to serve as a Substitute.
Apply at the Powhatan House.

div3.head: Substitute notice.
div3.p: --If Capt. F., who addressed "V.," at the Dispatch office, will call to day at Hotel up stairs, at 10 o'clock, he can have an interview.

div3.head: Wanted in Charlottesville.
div3.p:
--Six Substitutes.
Must be citizens of the Confederate States, and over forty-five.
To men of good moral character a good price will be paid.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --For the war. For a good and reliable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid by early application to Dr. Broocks, cor. Main and 12th st.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. This Substitute may have the privilege of joining any company he may wish to join.
A liberal price will be paid.
Address me on Marshall st., between 5th and 6th, three doors from the corner of 6th.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will give the above reward for the apprehension of my boy Charles, who left my promises about the 10th of January.
The said boy is a bright mulatto; about 18 years of age, and was hired last year at the Spotswood Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted — a Boy or man.
div3.p:
--I wish to hire a negro Boy or Man, free or slave to go to the Army of Tennessee--one who has been accustomed to horses preferred.
Apply at Mr. J. W Randolph's Bookstore, 121 Main street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a Virginia lady, a situation as Teacher in a private family.
She is competent to instruct small children in England Music on the Piano.
Address "Miss. G. J." Benito, Powhatan county, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A shout, good and gentle Horse, to work to an ambulance, for which from $200 to $300 will be paid.
Address &J. S.W.& Box 628.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To hire, a good Cook, Washer and Ironer, without husband or children.
For one of good character, a liberal price will be paid.
Please call at 41 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A No. 1 Washer and Ironer, (white preferred). Apply on the North side of Main street, first brick house above 31st

div3.head: Wanted — Gold Bullion.
div3.p:
--Any person having the above Bullion will bring or send it to No. 36 Main st., up stairs.
The best prices will be paid.
Also, Gold Epaulettes.

div3.head: Wanted — to hire.
div3.p:
--By the month a good Ox-Cart Driver, for which a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at once at

Ellett & Drewry's,
No. 17 Pearl street Richmond.
ja 27--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Compositor can obtain employment on this paper.
Apply to the soreman.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An A No. 1 Piano, (for hire or sale) at the Varieties Theatre for a season.
Apply to J. A. Clifford or D'O Ogden, Varieties Theatre, from 10 to 3 o'clock.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a young man who can bring good references, a Situation in a commission house.
Address "R." Box 311.

div3.head: Wanted — a Horse.
div3.p: --Any person having a No. 1 Draught Horse can find a purchaser by applying to
div3.closer:
J. M. Conrad,
Cary st. between 11th and 12th. ja 27--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --I wish to purchase, for my own use, a Boy from 12 to 15 years of age. He must be a boy of good character.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Board, in a private family, for a gentleman, his wife, and child six years of age, or one or two Rooms, furnished or unfurnished, with arrangements for cooking.
Address "C. H. H." Mississippi Depot.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Candy Maker.
Apply to A Pepri.
57 Main street, 2d door from 13th street, opposite St. Charles Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A copy of Gilhams Manual for Volunteers.
A liberal price will be paid for a copy of the above work.
Apply at the office of the Spotswood Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Teacher in a private family, in the city of Richmond, or its immediate vicinity, by a Virginia lady competent to teach a full course of English, and thoroughly qualified to teach Music on the Piano.
Address "B. V. Saxx," Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A German of a few years' experience would engage as Clerk in a Hotel or first class Restaurant.
Address "N. F. G." through Richmond P. O.

div3.head:
By Benson & Bro., Auct'rs.
[Charlottesville, Va.]
div3.p: Commissioner's Sale of Twenty Slaves.--I will sell at public auction, on Monday, Feb'y 2, 1863 (Albemarle Court day,) in the town of Charlottesville--
Twenty Slaves,
Eighteen of whom are young and likely.
div3.closer:
Jas. D. Jones, Com'r.
Sale by Benson & Bro, Aucts. ja 27--6t*

div3.head: Land, Negroes, &c., for Sale.
div3.p:
--The undersigned are authorized to sell a large and well improved Farm, lying in a desirable section, very near to the James River Canal, and within a convenient distance of Richmond.
It produces fine tobacco, and all other staple crops.
The improvements are good.
If desired the Slaves and Stock would be sold with the land.
A reasonable price will be taken for all the property.
Apply to
div3.closer:
W. & W. S. Peters.
Com'n Merchants, 12th st., South of Cary.
Richmond. Va. ja 27--d&sw2w

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--From what I can learn, my negro boy George left Richmond on Friday morning last at the servant of a gentleman connected with the Army of the Potomac.
He is about 16 years old, of yellow or brown color, with rather a full face and large eyes.
If my information is correct, the gentleman will please let me hear from him immediately.

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders.
div3.p:
--Information wanted of James M. Mosby, of Baltimore.
He enlisted in April, 1861, and went to Fort Pickens.
The undersigned has valuable news for him, and would like to hear of his whereabouts.
div3.closer:
R. S. Powers.
Ballard House.
Charleston Mercury please copy. ja 27--6t*

div3.head: Five hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --I will give $500 reward for the apprehension and conviction of the scoundrel who set my store on fire on the morning of the 26th January.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--One Cook, one House Servant, and two boys.
Apply at corner of Grace and Madison sts.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--By the month, a nice Hguan Maid.
She is also a good Nurse.
Apply to Dr. Follardo, Governor st.

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p:
--A Fine sized and very finely yellow Boy, nineteen or twenty years old. He is very capable, a swift, active waiter, and quite a good cook; would make a capital servant for an officer.
Apply at Grady's

div3.head:
By Hill, Dickinson & Co., Aucts.
Commissioner's Sale of negro woman.
div3.p: --Under a decree of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond, in the suit of Brooks and others vs Thaw and wife, and others, I will sell on Wednesday, 28th of January, 1863, at 10 o'clk, at the auction house of Hill, Dickinson & Co., a negro woman named Sarah, for cash.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 25th Dec'r last my negro man Patrick.
He is about 28 years of age, about five feet, seven inches high, very black, large thick lips, his under one turns entirely over, and large feet and hands.
He has been engaged in driving from my farm, in Henrico, to the city of Richmond for several years past.--He may be lurking about the city, or in some of the camps around.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and return to me.

div3.head: Public Sale of Twenty likely young Negroes in the Upper end of Goochland County.
div3.p:
--On Tuesday, the 27th day of January, 1863, on the White Hall road, at the late residence of George T. Marthews, now occupied by Capt. Pancuill.
Jr., five miles Northeast from Columbia, will be told by auction twenty young Negroes — men, women girls and horse I rough carpenter, cook and latin dress.
Persons attending the sale from Richmond will arrive at Columbia at six o'clock A. M., and those from Lynchburg Saturday evening previous to day of sale.
By packet boat conveyance may be had from Columbia to the sale.
Will be sold at the same time three yokes of heavy Oxen and other Cattle, force young and well broke Harness horses, Ox Wagon, four horse Wagon, &c. A. M. Haricton.

closer.signed: Agent and Auctioneer for Capt. George Pann't U. S. A.
